message: Improving college affordability and accessibility in Illinois is one of my top priorities as Senator. I’m glad I got the chance to sit down with Loyola University President Rooney today to discuss how we can best serve undocumented students and secure Title IV funding for student financial aid.

Now more than ever, America needs a State Department leader who is an ambassador for our best values and democratic ideals. Our nation needs a chief diplomat to advocate for what is right and stand up to President Trump when he is wrong. Unfortunately, Mr. Rex Tillerson – the President’s pick for Secretary of State – has done nothing to convince me he is that person.  Instead, Mr. Tillerson failed to criticize Russian aggression in Syria, Crimea and Eastern Ukraine. He failed to dissuade concerns about conflicts of interests. He failed to show independence from President Trump. And he failed to definitively condemn a Muslim registry, something that is absolutely unacceptable, especially in light of the President’s recent executive order. America needs someone with diplomatic experience leading the State Department, not an oil tycoon whose close ties to Russia and decades spent negotiating ExxonMobil business deals raise a number of conflict of interest issues. For all of these reasons, I voted against his nomination.

Habitat for Humanity offers critical assistance to communities in need of safe, affordable housing options and renovated public infrastructure, while also providing thousands of Americans with the opportunity to serve their community and their country. Today, I met with Habitat representatives to discuss the important work the organization is performing throughout Illinois and how we can expand national service opportunities for more Americans.
Had a productive meeting with Bloomingdale Mayor Franco  Coladipietro about how to diversify Bloomingdale’s economy and support hardworking families in DuPage County.

Given his record of opposing American-made renewable energy like the Renewable Fuel Standard, EPA nominee Scott Pruitt had a lot to answer for at his confirmation hearing. Instead, he provided evasive, hollow answers that were designed to sound good but meant little, which is why I oppose his nomination to the EPA. Achieving American energy independence and security requires an EPA Administrator who will defend, not destroy, our nation’s RFS program. The American people deserve honest, transparent EPA leadership. AG Pruitt falls short of this standard, from refusing to comply with long-standing open records requests, to misrepresenting his environmental justice record as the Oklahoma AG.

I commend the Department of Homeland Security’s Inspector General for acting swiftly on Senator Durbin’s and my request for an immediate investigation into the Federal Government’s chaotic implementation of President Trump’s discriminatory, potentially unconstitutional executive order. Wasting taxpayer dollars on unwarranted and unjust detentions of lawful permanent residents is shameful and un-American. The protections enshrined in our Constitution mean little if law enforcement agents feel empowered by the President to disregard them or if Americans are unwilling to defend them. The American people are relying on this investigation to help ensure that this President does not trample upon anyone’s constitutional rights or overreach through either malice or ignorance.
I’m wearing red today to help raise awareness about the importance of heart health screenings for women. Together, we can #KnockOutHeartDisease.
Welcome back to Chicago, Dr. Al Homssi. America is great because of doctors like you. #ImmigrantsWelcome #NoHateNoFear

I'm disappointed the President blocked implementation of the so-called “Fiduciary Rule,” that would have required retirement advisors to provide families saving for retirement with financial advice that is in the clients’ best interests. Without this rule, retirement advisors will be allowed to steer their clients towards more expensive funds with higher fees – robbing families saving for retirement an estimated $17 billion each year.   Stopping Wall Street investment advisors from taking advantage of consumers should be a top priority for a President who ran for office pledging to be above the influence of special interests. Instead, President Trump has stocked his administration with former Goldman Sachs employees who are eager to maintain a status quo that robs families saving for retirement of billions of dollars each year. That can mean the difference between enjoying a comfortable retirement and having to sacrifice or skimp on food, housing, health care, transportation and other necessities. The Trump administration clearly didn’t learn the right lesson from last year’s Wells Fargo scandal, but the victims did. If you reward bad behavior like this, bad behavior is what American families will get.
BREAKING: Federal judge orders immediate nationwide halt on #Trump’s #MuslimBan—this is great progress but this fight is not over.

Today, at a roundtable discussion with local Muslim leaders at the Islamic Center of Naperville I heard firsthand about the devastating effects of President Trump’s #MuslimBan. Last night's federal court order temporarily blocking implementation is a great step, but we must #EndTheBan for good.

I’m honored to celebrate the annual Black History Family Festival in Elgin by commemorating the work of local African American educators, and all the African American leaders who have come before us to shape our nation.
This past weekend, I was proud to attend the annual Equality Illinois Gala to support #LGBTQ rights in Illinois and across the country.
Glad to join Illinois AFGE members today to discuss the important ways government employees, many of whom are Veterans, serve the American people.

I voted against Betsy DeVos’ nomination to be Secretary of Education today because I don’t believe the President nominated the best candidate; I don’t even believe he nominated a qualified candidate. Ms. DeVos has never taught, never worked in a school system, and she has no degree in education policy. She failed to study for her confirmation hearing and she was unprepared and unfamiliar with a foundational civil rights law that guarantees every student, including those with disabilities, the right to a quality, equitable education.   I would not be here today were it not for strong public schools and civil rights protections so there was simply no way I could support her nomination. It is a shame that she will now helm the agency tasked with educating our children and training our workforce. Unfortunately, our children and our nation will suffer the consequences of this decision for decades to come.
The President’s #MuslimBan has devastated families across our nation. Let's #EndTheBan for good.

The Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory (Fermilab), located in Batavia, Illinois, is one of our state’s crown jewels of scientific innovation and I’m committed to supporting and expanding the national lab as a member of the Energy and Natural Resources Committee. Today, I was pleased to meet with Dr. Nigel Lockyer, the Director of Fermilab to discuss how we can best support scientific infrastructure in Illinois as a key source of economic growth and job creation.

Today I heard from experts on America’s refugee program from Refugee Council USA about the critical importance of welcoming refugees. The America that I know is not a nation that turns its back on children and families fleeing barbarism or terror; that is an action of a scared nation—of a weak nation—and it does not make us safer, though it does place our troops serving abroad at greater risk. Our nation is at its best when we lead from a position of strength, not weakness, as organizations like the Refugee Council know well. While this weekend’s court ruling that temporarily blocked implementation of the President’s ill-conceived and misguided travel ban is a good signal, we must remember that this fight is not over. I will continue working every day to end this ban for good.

After I was injured in Iraq, I learned how important laws like the Americans with Disabilities Act are to ensuring millions of Americans with disabilities can live and thrive with dignity. Who the Attorney General is matters because they get to decide whether to enforce or erode the protections countless Americans depend on.   Senator Sessions voted against expanding hate crime protections to people with disabilities. He’s called protections for people with disabilities “unnecessary” and even “dangerous.” He’s called laws requiring public schools accommodate students with physical and learning disabilities like ADHD, “the single most irritating problem for teachers throughout America today.” If Senator Sessions is confirmed, I am deeply concerned about what will happen to citizens with disabilities, to citizens with different racial backgrounds, to citizens with different sexual orientations and to other marginalized Americans.

Since 1918, Australia and the US have fought side by side in every major conflict, making 2018 a year to commemorate 100 years of an invaluable relationship between the United States and Australia. I had the privilege of meeting with Australian Ambassador Joe Hockey this week to discuss the importance of a strong US-Australia relationship for decades to come, especially as it pertains to our national security and safety.

Every Illinoisan deserves access to quality, affordable health care, no matter where they live. At a meeting today with Illinois Critical Access Hospital Network, we discussed how we can work together to ensure local health facilities have access to the resources they need to best serve hardworking families in rural communities across Illinois.

I’m grateful for the chance to meet with Dr. Kenneth Polonsky, the CEO of the University of Chicago Medical Center, to learn more about how UCMC is working to deliver quality #healthcare to underserved communities.

America needs a forceful advocate for fairness in its next Attorney General—someone who will fight for justice for all people—not a rubber stamp for the President. Unfortunately, Senator Sessions’ record and refusal to recuse himself from voting on other Trump nominees proves he will not be that person.   Senator Sessions voted against extending hate crime protections to Americans who are targeted because of their gender, disability or sexual orientation. He argued for religious discrimination against Muslims. He wanted to pass a constitutional amendment outlawing same-sex marriage and criticized legal protections for people with disabilities as "irritating" and "unnecessary."   I am disappointed that Senator Sessions will now be in a position to erode the civil rights countless Americans bled to protect. I worry about what his Department of Justice will mean for our neighbors with disabilities, Americans of all sexual orientations, people of color and others who have historically been denied equal protection under our nation’s laws when public officials entrusted to enforce those protections turned a blind eye.

The opioid crisis is devastating our communities in Illinois and all across the country, and we cannot afford to lose any more of our young Illinoisans to drug overdose and abuse. Resolving this crisis requires a comprehensive, fully funded effort from officials at every level of government, and from local community organizations like the Lake County Underage Drinking and Drug Prevention Task Force, which I met with this week. As a Senator, I will work to support federal resources for prevention efforts and addiction treatment, which includes keeping life-saving anti-opioid drugs affordable for the average consumer.

Yesterday, I asked the Inspector General of the Department of Homeland Security for an update on the investigation Senator Dick Durbin and I helped launch into the potentially illegal implementation of President Trump’s #MuslimBan, and I hope to hear back soon. Independent investigations like this one are an important way to make sure our government is accountable and respects the Constitution.

I would not be where I am today if it were not for my public school and the public school teachers who believed in me when I was growing up. I enjoyed the chance to meet with National Education Association directors from Illinois today and our discussion about how we can work to ensure Illinois #publicschools have the support they need to best serve their communities – because investments in our schools are investments in our families, our workforce and our economy.
Was great to meet with so many civically-engaged students from Chicagoland today about the importance of strong US-Israel relations
BREAKING: 9th Circuit just ruled in favor of our Constitutional values & denied POTUS attempt to reinstate #MuslimBan. Momentum on our side!
Good to meet with NARAL President Ilyse Hogue this week. I’ll continue to protect against attempts to roll back the progress we’ve made on women’s rights.

Kellyanne Conway’s use of White House resources to sell Ivanka Trump’s fashion line appears to have violated federal conflict of interest laws. The White House should not use government resources to help private companies.
Welcome home, U.S. Army PFC Bilyeu. Thank you for your service and sacrifice; you’ve earned the appreciation of a grateful state and nation.

Whether illegally foreclosing on thousands of families, skirting the law with offshore tax havens or helping design tactics that contributed to the 2008 financial crisis, Treasury Secretary nominee Steve #Mnuchin made a career – and millions of dollars – pioneering increasingly deceptive and predatory ways to rob hardworking Americans of their savings and homes.   Greed and unethical behavior may be skills valued by the Trump administration, but it is the Senate’s job to check the President when he is wrong. Mr. #Mnuchin will not join the cabinet with my vote.

I’m proud of my Thai-American heritage. Today I had the pleasure of meeting with Floyd Mori, President & CEO of the Asian Pacific American Institute for Congressional Studies, to discuss how we can work together to serve the AAPI community and all Illinois families by supporting local businesses, investing in manufacturing and making college more affordable.
Illinois State Treasurer Mike Frerichs and I had a great conversation today about the importance of ensuring all Illinoisans are able to save for a secure and dignified retirement.

By reportedly misleading the Vice President-elect about his collusion with a foreign government to undermine our nation's foreign policy, General Michael Flynn left himself exposed to blackmail, betrayed our country’s interests and lost the trust of both the Commander in Chief and the American people. Like so many of his poorly-vetted and ethically-challenged senior advisors and Cabinet nominees, President Trump should never have chosen Flynn for such a critically important role; the General’s resignation was long overdue. The American people deserve a full and transparent accounting of what President Trump and his top aides knew and when they knew it. If the President cannot or will not provide those answers, Congress must use its authority as a coequal branch of government to fully investigate why.

I’m working every day to help end our nation’s gun violence problem, and was pleased to meet today with Illinois members of the National Fraternal Order of Police and discuss what needs to be done to strengthen public safety efforts while rebuilding trust between law enforcement and the communities most affected by violence.

Had a productive meeting today with Joe Szabo, the Executive Director Chicago Metropolitan Agency for Planning, about rebuilding our state’s infrastructure to create jobs and secure Illinois’ role as the nation’s transportation hub.

Serving my community and my country has always been a driving force in my life and I believe all Americans deserve the opportunity to give back to their country—in or out of uniform. Just as picking up a gun to defend our country is "American Service," so is picking up a soup spoon to feed the less fortunate, a stick of chalk to reach low-income children or a hammer to rebuild homes for those devastated by natural disasters. I was honored and humbled to receive Voices for National Service's Outstanding National Service Advocacy Award tonight, and I look forward to working with them to ensure more Americans have the opportunity to serve their communities and their country.
Enjoyed the chance to learn more about urban horticulture from Chicago Botanic Garden President and CEO, Jean Franczyk.

Did you know that retirement advisors do not have to provide advice that is in their clients' best interests? Instead, they are free to steer clients towards more expensive financial products with higher fees, a practice that costs families saving for retirement an estimated $17 billion a year.  The Obama administration finalized a rule to change this but President Trump is poised to prevent it from taking effect. As I wrote in a column for Crain's Chicago Business today, has Washington learned nothing from the Wells Fargo scandal? If we allow big banks to reward bad behavior, bad behavior is what we will get.

Last month, I met several workers who were denied paid leave and were required to serve & prep food when they were sick while they worked for Andrew Puzder's fast food corporation. No one should be forced to choose between taking care of themselves or a sick family member and earning a paycheck they cannot afford to go without. It was a mistake to nominate someone like Mr. Puzder considering he has spent his career exploiting workers and racking up labor violations. I hope the President chooses someone more qualified to lead the Labor Department.

No matter where I am in Illinois – from rural towns to urban cities –  I often hear the same thing: Illinoisans are ready, willing and eager to start rebuilding our state’s infrastructure. That’s why today I called for a significant investment in our nation’s transportation system to modernize Illinois railways.    Any serious effort to upgrade our nation’s freight rail system must prioritize Illinois. Chicago is the busiest rail hub in America and East St. Louis is another major rail center. Hundreds of millions of tons of freight volume pass through Illinois every year. Our state is the heart of our country’s freight supply chain, and if Illinois’ supply chain arteries are clogged, our entire nation will suffer.    Upgrading our rail capacity, speed and reliability would not only support new economic opportunities for hardworking Illinoisans, but it would also strengthen our whole nation’s economy.
I'm about to speak about how Scott #Pruitt is unfit to serve as the head of the EPA. Tune in! https://www.periscope.tv/w/1YqJDXYezgDJV

I was only able to afford to go to college because of Pell Grants, student loans and a part-time waitressing job, so I understand the critical importance of student aid and making college more affordable. It was great to meet with trustees from community colleges around Illinois this week and I’ll keep working to ensure our state’s community colleges receive the support they need to serve Illinois’s students and keep higher education accessible and affordable for families.

America is at its best when we welcome immigrants who work hard every day to build a better life for themselves and their families. Ordering local officials to needlessly tear families apart is unacceptable – and it compromises public safety in communities across Illinois by fostering mistrust and suspicion between local law enforcement and the communities they serve and protect. I stand with the people of Cicero, of Evanston, of Urbana and of Chicago and my Senate colleagues against these sorts of divisive actions in favor of the inclusive America I know we can be.

Last night, I spoke for an hour on the Senate floor against Scott Pruitt’s nomination to lead the EPA. As someone who fought to defend this nation, I’ve seen firsthand the price we pay for our dangerous dependence on foreign oil. We should be encouraging the use of American-made renewable fuel through programs like the Renewable Fuel Standard, not appointing people like Mr. Pruitt who has questioned the science of climate change and used the Attorney General’s office in Oklahoma to help big oil sue the EPA to dismantle public health protections.   As the mom of a 2-year-old, I was also shocked that Mr. Pruitt was unaware that there is no safe level of lead for children at his confirmation hearing. That is a significant oversight especially in the aftermath of the Flint Water Crisis. Lead in schools and public water supplies is a serious problem for children in Illinois and across this nation, which is why we need an EPA that will proactively prevent crises like Flint. Unfortunately, Mr. Pruitt's record of filing lawsuit after lawsuit undermining the agency’s ability to carry out its mission doesn't inspire much confidence.

Everyone deserves access to opportunity and a healthy, happy life—we have so much more to do to get there though. We have to invest in communities that have been ignored for too long, to revitalize neighborhoods around our state in ways that help people pick themselves up by their own bootstraps. That’s what I’m working to do in the United States Senate and I’m pleased I was able to meet with Chicago Southwest Development Corporation President Guy Medaglia this week to discuss projects like the Focal Point campus, a one million square foot multipurpose complex designed to provide essential retail, education, wellness and health services to more than 400,000 residents of Chicago’s West and Southwest Sides.

Last spring, travelers at Chicago O’Hare International Airport faced excessive wait times at the airport, and I called on Congress to do its part to fix the issue. This week I reiterated my request to enhance the Transportation Security Administration’s (TSA) workforce and remove the arbitrary cap on the number of screeners TSA may employ to protect our national security and reduce excessive airport wait times –  especially in light of the absence of a nominee to be the next TSA Administrator.   As a Senator who proudly represents Illinois, home to Chicago O’Hare International Airport – one of the busiest airports in the world – I understand how critical aviation security is to our counterterrorism efforts, and to preventing long wait times for travelers. To avoid the long lines travelers experienced last spring at O’Hare, TSA must have flexibility to hire, train and deploy screeners based on fluctuating travel volumes. TSA’s counterterrorism mission is, and must always remain, the agency’s highest priority. That is why Congress should remove the arbitrary annual cap on full-time TSA screeners. When it comes to protecting travelers, TSA’s staffing decisions must be based on real world mission needs, not unjustified congressional mandates that make our entire nation less safe.

Proud to join my colleagues in support of the lawsuit against President Trump’s #MuslimBan. The government’s actions sanctioning discrimination are an affront to American values and our constitutional principles of religious freedom and equal protection under the law.

Enjoyed talking to State Representative Welch, Recorder Yarbrough and Hillside Mayor Tamburino at Priscilla’s Ultimate Soulfood Cafeteria in Hillside, Illinois, to discuss our efforts to support small businesses and Illinois families. If we want to create new economic opportunities for working families, we are going to need to make it easier for local businesses to get off the ground. I’m proud to serve on the Senate Committee on Small Business & Entrepreneurship because it helps me advocate for the kinds of investments that help small businesses like Priscilla’s grow and create more jobs.

Racial or religious profiling by law enforcement goes against our Constitution and our core values as Americans. I’m proud to be an original cosponsor of the End Racial and Religious Profiling Act of 2017 to ensure equal protection under the law and protect against discriminatory profiling.
Grateful to join the People’s Church of the Harvest yesterday during a beautiful weekend in Chicago.

Ordering government officials to needlessly tear families apart is unacceptable and it fosters mistrust and suspicion between law enforcement and the communities they protect. That’s why I’ve joined with 20 of my colleagues to introduce legislation to repeal the President’s executive order on immigration.

Enjoyed getting the chance to meet with Debra Crockett, Associate Executive Director of Angelic Organics Learning Center in Caledonia, Illinois, to discuss how we can work together to ensure local farmers have the resources they need to support sustainable food and farm systems.  Growing up, my family had to rely on food stamps to make ends meet, so I understand the critical role organizations like Angelic Organics Learning Center play in ensuring all families have access to healthy food sources. I will continue to push for federal investments in local farming and urban agriculture to create more self-sustaining communities and healthy food options for low-income families—and all families—across the state.

It was great to meet with Rockford Police Chief Dan O’Shea today about public safety issues & hear about how I can support the city of Rockford as Illinois’s newest Senator. I’m looking forward to his plan to strengthen police-community relations by encouraging police officers to live in the neighborhoods they serve & protect, which is modeled after a successful program run by the city of Elgin.

I was honored to speak at Secretary Jesse White’s annual African-American Heritage Month Celebration in Chicago today. We know that the true strength of this country lies in the diversity of its people, which is why I go to work each day to help ensure every American, no matter where they’re from, has the same opportunity to get a quality education, secure a good-paying job and create a life for their children that is better than their own. Too many young people, particularly young people of color, have their dreams and their ambitions stifled by lack of hope. To address this, we need economic justice. We need jobs, and we need investment in all of our communities. We need an education system that prepares our children for a fast-changing economy, no matter their zip code.  The bottom line is that when our families are working as hard as they can to get by but are still struggling to pay rent or put food on the table – our whole community suffers, our whole nation suffers. I will continue to do my part in the Senate to help expand economic opportunity, make education more accessible and create more vibrant communities across the state. We may have a lot of work ahead of us, but together we can make it happen.

Every American should have the opportunity to lead a healthy, productive life – including those with a mental or physical disability. Living with a disability comes with a unique set of challenges, which is something I know firsthand. I appreciate the chance to meet with Easter Seals leadership today to discuss how I can best support their efforts to support children with developmental disabilities through health and family support services. I will continue to advocate for disability rights in the Senate and work to ensure that every child has access to the care and support they deserve.

Had a great meeting with the leadership of Western Illinois University today about college affordability and how I can support the University and its surrounding community as Illinois’s newest Senator. I’m impressed by the excellent support WIU’s Veterans Resource Center provides for those who served our nation and will do what I can to help every student and every Veteran receive an education that prepares them for a good career.

I’m excited to announce that today is the official opening of my new Senate office in Springfield, and I’m grateful to see so many Illinoisans here to join me for the launch. My new Springfield office will help ensure hardworking families in central Illinois have access to a convenient and welcoming place to get assistance with federal agencies, small business development and federal benefits like Social Security, Veterans benefits and Medicare. One of my top priorities as Senator is ensuring my staff and I are accessible to Illinoisans in every corner of our state, and I look forward to opening more Senate offices across Illinois in the weeks and months ahead.

Had a productive meeting with local leaders in Quincy, Illinois, today to discuss the importance of rebuilding and modernizing Illinois’s infrastructure to create jobs and improve transportation systems statewide. It’s about time we made a serious investment in our nation’s interstate highway system and other projects like the Mid-America Intermodal Port and our locks and dams to create good-paying jobs and bolster Illinois’s status as a world-class air, road, rail and water transportation hub.  We also have a moral obligation to make sure our children’s drinking water is clean and safe, which means tearing out and replacing dangerous lead service lines that have poisoned far too many children. Lead contamination is a very serious issue for families across the country, I’m pleased we were also able to discuss how we can address these issues and others as I continue to advocate for policies to rebuild Illinois’s infrastructure statewide.

Glad I was able to bring together so many elected officials, local leaders and Chicagoland transportation agency officials for a roundtable this morning to discuss how we can boost our city’s economy and our entire nation’s economy by modernizing public transit systems and supporting other transportation infrastructure projects throughout the Chicagoland region.

Great to join members of Illinois State Society tonight to celebrate everything our great state has to offer. As Illinois’s newest Senator, I will continue to push for our state’s priorities like rebuilding Illinois’s infrastructure, keeping our water system safe and lead-free, helping grow minority- and Veteran-owned small businesses and investing in our manufacturing sector.

My guest at the President’s address to Congress tonight will be Mr. Abdulla Sindi, an Iraqi refugee who had to flee for his life after he worked with U.S. forces to enforce the no-fly zone following Operation Desert Storm. Abdulla became an American citizen in 2006 and immediately signed up to serve, training National Guardsmen before they deployed to Iraq and working as an interpreter for our military in Iraq, helping keep American Troops safe.   Abdulla would not have been able to enter America if a Muslim travel ban similar to President Trump’s had been in place. His presence at tonight’s address sends a powerful message that hardworking immigrants & refugees make our country a better place.
Spoke with leaders of the American Legion Department of Illinois about how we can work to ensure all Veterans receive the support and benefits they have earned defending our nation.

We need to ensure every child has access to quality health care, no matter where they’re from. Today, I met with Dr. Mariana Glusman, President-Elect of the Illinois Chapter of the American Academy of Pediatrics, to discuss how we can work together to serve children and their families across Illinois.

It's about time we expanded broadband services to empower all Illinois families with high-speed internet. Today I had a productive meeting with Mayor Wescott of Rock Falls about the importance of investing in infrastructure projects to create jobs and benefit Rock Falls and our state as a whole.
Watch my message to President Trump ahead of tonight's #JointSession:
Saddened to hear of loss of life in Ottawa. I hope all Illinoisans stay safe tonight during severe weather.

Since taking office President Trump’s record has been divisive & disheartening but I remained hopeful that he would view tonight as an opportunity to present the American people with a more positive and inclusive message to move us forward as a nation. Despite initial indications, vague platitudes about a bipartisan infrastructure plan and promises to rein in unfair trade practices, the President’s remarks tonight were anything but unifying.  He largely doubled down on the dark and dangerous rhetoric that has become a pillar of his fledgling Presidency, including his misguided Muslim travel ban and deeply flawed understanding of the causes of gun violence in Chicago and across the country. Tonight was an opportunity for the President to make good on his promises to the American people, to back up his rhetoric with action. He did neither, and his broken promises are beginning to add up.

Improving access to broadband internet service is important for communities across Illinois. In many rural areas of our state & in parts of Chicago, children cannot do their homework because they lack internet access or their families cannot afford it. As Rock Falls Mayor Bill Wescott told me yesterday, limited competition has left communities like his without internet they can afford. I was glad to have the chance to discuss the need to increase competition during today’s Senate Commerce Committee hearing & how to improve the government programs that are available to help.
Great to see J Street members from Illinois at the Capitol this week!

Great to talk to with Mr. Clayton Harris III, Executive Director of the Illinois International Port District, about initiatives to redevelop the Port of Chicago and create #jobs on the South Side of the city.
I'll be joining All In with Chris Hayes tonight on MSNBC at 8/7 pm CT to talk about how we need our Commander-in-Chief to act like one. Hope you'll tune in!
Met with the Illinois Municipal Electric Agency and the Illinois Municipal Utilities Association today to discuss how we can work together to boost the state economy.

Chicago Medical Society President Clarence Brown and I had a productive meeting about streamlining and improving our health care system, preventing prescription drug price increases and helping ensure that we’re properly training medical students and doctors to address the opioid crisis.
Was on All In with Chris Hayes last night to talk about how the President needs to stop blaming our military for his own orders & start acting like the Commander-in-Chief that he is.

AG #Sessions' decision to recuse himself was a necessary first step, but his #DOJ can't investigate itself. The American people deserve an independent investigation into his contacts & the entire Trump administration's connections w/ the Russians. Our #NationalSecurity & the integrity of our democracy could very well depend on it.

It’s important for me to hear directly from the people I represent. I’m grateful that I could meet with constituents this morning over coffee and donuts to discuss the needs of hardworking Illinois families alongside my dear friend and colleague, Senator Durbin.
Had a productive meeting this week with IL Dept. of Transportation Secretary, Randall Blankenhorn about how we can boost our economy and create jobs by modernizing Illinois transportation systems.

National service has always been a driving force in my life and expanding national service opportunities for all Americans is a top priority of mine in the Senate. This week, Executive Director of the Serve Illinois Commission, Scott McFarland and I discussed the importance of supporting AmeriCorps and other national service programs.

I met with Colonel Christopher Beck, Commander of the Louisville District, US Army Corps of Engineers this week about how we can strengthen our nation’s economy by enhancing the Olmsted Locks and Dam system located between Illinois and Kentucky, one of the busiest inland waterways in the country.
Grateful to have the chance to chat with members of Illinois Veterans of Foreign Wars this week!

Congressman Bost’s remarks are offensive and hurtful to Asian Americans and Asians around the world. In addition to owing his constituents a sincere apology, he should put more thought into his words in the future. Racism has no place in American political discourse.

Excited to announce I’ll be the Ranking Member of the Environment and Public Works Subcommittee on Fisheries, Water and Wildlife, which is tasked with keeping our water clean and preventing lead contamination in our water systems. We have a moral obligation to make sure our children’s drinking water is clean and safe, and as the top-ranking Democrat on this subcommittee I will do everything I can to ensure our water systems aren’t poisoning our children.  I also secured assignments to the Subcommittee on Transportation and Infrastructure and the Subcommittee on Clean Air and Nuclear Safety, where I will continue to advocate for infrastructure investments that create good-paying jobs and work to protect the Great Lakes from pollution and invasive species like the Asian carp.
I appreciated the chance to meet with members of The Disabled American Veterans from Illinois last week and enjoyed talking about how our country can improve services for all Veterans.

Just like his last #MuslimBan, this executive order plays into our enemy’s hands by giving them a propaganda tool to spread a false narrative about the United States hating Muslims. This ban will not make our country safer. It betrays the American values those of us who served in uniform fought to defend. Discrimination is discrimination and no amount of sugarcoating by the President will change that.  President Trump’s last #MuslimBan created chaos for my constituents and Americans across the nation. Multiple federal courts rightfully halted implementation over concerns surrounding its legality and constitutionality. I am confident this new order will not stand either, if not in the courts then at the ballot box.

I was honored to address members of the International Association of Fire Fighters today. Every community in this country, whether it be in rural Illinois or in our nation’s capital, relies on fire fighters each day to respond to an array of emergency situations. Our public safety depends upon their work, and I’ll continue my work to ensure our nation’s fire fighters have the resources they need to serve and protect our communities.

I relied on Pell Grants, student loans and a part-time waitressing job to pay for college, so I know how important making college more affordable can be. I’m glad I had the opportunity to chat with University of Chicago President Bob Zimmer about how we can work together to help make affordable higher education a reality for all Americans by expanding Pell Grants and allowing borrowers to refinance their student loans at lower rates.
Hateful threats against Jewish Americans are unacceptable. I condemn them & am calling for increased funding for security at JCC's & schools
Great to see Illinois members of the Delta Sigma Theta Sorority today in DC!
On #AAPIEqualPay Day, we are reminded that Asian American women still make less than their white male counterparts for the same work. It’s about time we had #equalpayforequalwork.

I’m alarmed at what appears to be another Trump Administration official misleading Congress as they sought confirmation from the United States Senate. We should expect nothing less than the truth from those seeking to serve the public, but we’ve now learned that EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt was less than forthcoming—at least twice—during his confirmation hearing before the Environment and Public Works Committee that I’m honored to serve on.   When then-nominee Pruitt was asked if he used his personal email address for business or official purposes he claimed he did not. It took a court order, but we now know that he did. Administrator Pruitt also claimed during his confirmation hearing that he did not question the science behind climate change—science that 97% of scientists agree on—then turned around and told CNBC that he doesn’t believe CO2 is the primary contributor to climate change.    The American people deserve leadership in Washington that they can trust, but this President and his appointees continue to show they don’t deserve it. Unfortunately, in the case of Administrator Pruitt, dishonesty could put millions of lives throughout the country at stake. We can—and should—do much better.

STARTING NOW: I am giving my maiden speech on the U.S. Senate floor. It’s truly an honor to be speaking on the Senate floor today, at the same desk once held by President Obama. Thank you to my friend and mentor, Senator Durbin, for being here today. Though we've occasionally made choices that don't reflect our best selves, we're the greatest nation in the world due to our ideals and values. These shared values that have helped us to strive toward that more perfect union the Constitution’s framers envisioned. Falling victim to fear & demagoguery will only ensure a weaker America for our children, and that’s not a future I want for my two-year-old daughter.   America wasn’t founded as the dominant economic and military force and leader of the free world — the American people built that. From our founding, the US has faced stark divisions and challenges. But through each trial, we have emerged a more perfect union. We might get knocked down, but the America I know—that I fought for and love—does not give up. It's the American way.   Some may try to convince us the path forward is less engagement with the world, less acceptance of others and less investment in ourselves. But I know that the path forward for our country cannot include—does not include—turning our backs on the shared values that built our nation.   Progress is never a sure thing—it's won through the hard work and toil of our Servicemembers, Veterans, manufacturers, farmers, teachers and civil rights leaders. And our nation wouldn’t be as strong as it is today without the millions of individuals who sacrificed to build it. Our nation’s strength—what makes American great—is rooted firmly in our shared sense of sacrifice.   We know we still have a lot work to do as a country, but let us not lose sight of the core values that make our improbable union possible. We're still the greatest nation in the world, and if anyone has the capacity to overcome the challenges of today, it’s the American people.

It is my privilege to be at Washington University in St. Louis today to honor and celebrate our Veterans and servicemembers, and the commitment they have made to serve our nation.   Many of these Veterans choose to continue serving their nation after they leave active service. The mission is always the same, but the path of service just looks a little different. The work many of our Veterans are doing—including those at WashU—to pursue degrees in social work, law or business is still part of their path to serving their fellow Americans, and I am deeply grateful for their service.   So today—and every day of the year—it’s important that we honor all that our nation’s heroes have done for our country. That means making sure our Vets can find good-paying jobs, affordable higher education, housing and access to high quality health care when they return home. To each of them, to all of my fellow Veterans, and to all of their families, thank you from the bottom of my heart. You are true heroes. God bless you, God bless our troops in harm’s way and God bless the United States of America.
